title: Pascal Chimbonda says Mauricio Pochettino is not to blame for Tottenham's struggles but Daniel Levy
text:
Pascal Chimbonda believes Mauricio Pochettino is not to blame for Tottenham's poor start to the season but rather the lack of investment in the squad from chairman Daniel Levy.

Spurs have won just three out of 12 games in the Premier League so far this season and are on a desperate winless away run that dates back to January last season.

This has led to some to say the Argentine, who before this torrid run has barely put a foot wrong at the club, may be on his way out.

Pascal Chimbonda believes Spurs poor form is down to a lack of investment in the squad

But former Spurs right-back Chimbonda believes the blame does not lie at Pochettino's door, but rather at the lack of investment in the squad he has at his disposal from those above him.

'It's been pretty much the same team for two years in a row, and if you want to be a big team, you have to buy players and keep your squad fresh,' Chimbonda told Gambling.com.

'I don't think they should change the manager. I think some players' heads have gone and the manager has no alternative options, and that's what's causing problems in the Spurs team.

'Sometimes Pochettino only has one player available in a certain position, and that's not necessarily his fault. Things have become stale because of the lack of options.'

Chimbonda believes Pochettino is not to blame, rather Daniel Levy's lack of squad investment

Tottenham's 1-1 draw with bottom-of-the-table Watford at the weekend did nothing to appease the mounting pressure growing at the Tottenham Hotspur stadium following 7-2 and 3-0 defeats to Bayern Munich and Brighton in the space of a week before the international break.

But Chimbonda believes the former Southampton manager, who took Spurs to an unlikely Champions League final last season, will be given time to turn things around.

'You never know in football. Things can happen at any time and managers can leave in an instant, but I don't think Daniel Levy would take that decision right now.

'Even if they get a bad result in the Champions League on Tuesday, I don't think anything will happen, I think he'll wait until closer to January to see if things have improved and, if not, then maybe he'll consider his options.'

The Frenchman played for Spurs for two spells between 2006 and 2009 and was part of the side that won the League Cup in 2008, the last trophy the club have won.

Pochettino's men host Red Star Belgrade in the Champions League on Tuesday night, with their first win in the competition crucial to having any chance of qualifying from Group B.
description: Former Tottenham Hotspur right-back Pascal Chimbonda (left) believes Mauricio Pochettino (right) is not to blame for Spurs' poor start to the season but rather at the lack of squad investment.
